COL.DATA: The scenes from the Passion start from the southwest end in the upper part of the walls of the church and continue all along the west and south side. These scenes are the Last Supper, the Washing of the Feet, the Prayer in the Garden of Gethsemane, the Betrayal, Jesus before Pilate, the Road to Calvary, the Crucifixion, the Descent from the Cross, the Lamentation, almost completely damaged, the Anastasis (Resurrection) and the "Noli me Tangere" ("Don't Touch me") scene.
Church of the Holy Cross, Nave, Passion scenes

In the west part of the cell is situated the stone bed of Neophytos (0,40m high, 0,63m wide and 1,73m long). Behind the bed there is a rectangular niche in which the library of Neophytos where his books were kept. In front of the bed there is a built table covered with a flat slab (0,85Ã—0,56m) which was used by Neophytos as desk. The niche in which Neophytos himself hewed his tomb in the rock is on the east half of the cell's north wall. This niche is decorated on its three sides. (On the east wall of the cell there is a narrow and low entrance which, according to some tradition, was opened following the discovery of the relics of the Saint Neophytos in 1756 to allow women to visit the saint's tomb.) Two small windows high on the east wall allow light to get through into the Neophytos' cell. The ceiling of the cell is completely uneven. On the south wall of the cell there are two layers of paintings. Small parts of the oldest layer are discernible. It seems that originally the Crucifixion scene was somewhat more narrow and in it apart from the Crucified Christ only the Virgin and Saint John the Evangelist were depicted, while further to the east another saint in a broader frame was depicted.
Cell of Neophytos and its Wall Paintings
The narrow door on the south wall of the narthex lead to a cell.
A cell south of the narthex

A narrow stone-built staircase with 23 steps leads to the narthex of the Enkeistra, at a height of 4,75 metres. The narthex is trapezoidal in shape and is covered with a vault. A narrow door on the north wall lead the to the porch where the Refectory.
The sacristy is located above the narthex. It communicates through a small opening with the church.

The narthex was decorated with mural paintings early in the 16th century. They are similar in style to the wall paintings of the main church of the Monastery. Only a few yet faded wall paintings have survived.
The wall painting depicting the Annunciation to the Virgin adorns the spandrel above the entrance to the Church of the Holy Cross. It survives in good condition.

The narthex was decorated with wall paintings similar in style to the wall paintings of the main church (Katholikon) of the Monastery of Agios Neophytos. Only a few wall paintings have survived. Yet wall paintings to the right and the left of the entrance to the Church of the Holy Cross have been poorly preserved.

Saint Peter and Saint Gregory the Theologian are displayed to the left while Saint Paul and Saint Sabas to the right of the entrance to the Church of the Holy Cross. Saint Gregory, Bishop of Nyssa, is depicted on the east side of the nearby niche. The image of Saint Nicholas is poorly preserved.on the north wall.

An inscription in the southwest corner of the church mentions that the church of the Enkleistra was hewn, built and painted with the contribution and much toil of Agios Neophytos in 1196, while in 1503 "the present part of the decoration and many other decorations and essential things were renovated" with money provided by the "humble" monk Neophytos. (The inscription gives wrongly 1196 as the date of the hewing of the Enkleistra instead of the correct date 1159 (hewing) and 1183 (early decoration) which the Saint himself mentions and is confirmed by the inscription which has survived in the Saint's cell.)
Long inscription. Dates. Church of the Holy Cross.

An inscription which survives on the north wall of Neophytos' cell mentions the year 1183 for an early decoration of the Enkleistra which is also confirmed by Neophytos himself in his Testamentary Rule of 1214. Beneath the Supplication (Deesis), this partly damaged inscription mentions also the name of the painter: "The Enkleistra... was painted completely by the hand of Theodoros Apseudes in the year 6691 indiction 1". The year 6691 from the creation of the world correspond to the year 1183. As it is known, the Byzantines believed that Christ was born in the year 5508 from the creation of the world. Thus deducting the year 5508 from the year 6691 we find the year 1183.
Long inscription. Wall painting. Cell of Neophytos

The Refectory of the Monastery of the Enkleistra or the "Refectory tou Aristou" (ariston means the lunch), as Neophytos calls it, is situated to the north of the Neophytos'cell. Like all Byzantine refectories, it too was originally completely decorated with wall paintings. Today only a small part of these wall paintings survive. On the west wall, over the standing monastic saints there are two layers of wall paintings. On the more recent layer, the vision of Prophet Isaiah seem to have been depicted.
Refectory of the Monastery of the Enkleistra or the "Refectory tou Aristou"

The lower zone of the west side of the church is adorned with images of twelve saintly monks as models of monastic life. The inscriptions which are written on the srolls they are holding encourage monks to be humble, to repent of their sins and to put their faith in God above love for their parents. These saintly monks are, from the left to the right, Antonios, Arsenios, Efthymios, Amoun Nitriotis, Andronicos, Daniel Skitiotis, Theodosios the Coenobiarch, John of Klimakos, Onoufrios, Makarios. Paisios and Stephanos the Young. With the exception of Stephanos the Young, who lived in the 8th century and suffered martyrdom from the iconoclasts, the other saintly monks lived in the period of the 4th-6th century.
Church of the Holy Cross, Nave, Saintly Monks

Originally, before 1196, there was no iconostasis but a narrow entrance like that which joins the bema to the cell of Neophytos. Indeed, above the iconostasis and beneath the decorative band with the vermiculation which is part of the painting of the Passion scenes a combination of the letters O and A, which stand for the words O Agios (the saint), in an earlier layer of painting, has survived. It seems that where there is today the icon of the Virgin on the iconostasis of 1796 there was a wall painting of a standing saint painted on the south side of the wall that separated the main church from the bema. There was another wall painting where on the iconostasis there is the icon of Christ. To the right on the north wall Christ is painted enthroned. On the east end of the wall a small part of a saintly bishop has survived.
Wall that separated the main church from the bema with narrow entrance which joins the nave to the bema

A rectangular niche with a cross-shaped niche is formed on the east wall of the Church of the Holy Cross. This cross-shaped niche was originally larger and had the dimensions of the wooden cross which is displayed today in front of it. This wooden cross, which originally believed to have contained a piece of the True Cross which Neophytos had sought and found was in the niche of the wall.
Church of the Holy Cross, Nave, East wall, rectangular niche

But who is the head of a monk depicted on the east wall of the nave in the Church of the Holy Cross. He is accompanied by the end of an inscription "[-------] humble monk". Scholars, like Athanasios Papageorghiou have identified this figure with Isaias, Neophytos' nephew and successor based on the assumption that the surviving mural decoration of the nave dates after 1214. He also mentions that this accounts for the differences between this image and the two images of Neophytos in the bema and in his cell.
Church of the Holy Cross, Nave, Enigmatic figure of a humble monk

The bema of the Church of the True Cross of the Enkleistra is on the north side of the church on account of the morphology of the cave which Neophytos transformed into a church. The altar is located on the east side of the bema. The ceiling of the bema is very uneven. On the west part it is very low while it ascends steeply and forms an uneven oval "dome" at its highest point over the altar. The display of the Ascension at this highest point of the ceiling of the bema echoes the morphology of the cave.
Church of the Holy Cross. Bema
